definitions.sensetop: expensive to doexpensive for somebodyexpensive for somebody to doit is expensive to do somethingit is expensive for somebody to do something

examples.text: I can't afford it—it's too expensive.
Making the wrong decision could **prove expensive**.
Art books are expensive to produce.
The new regulations are likely to be very expensive for employers.
Bonds can be expensive for individuals to invest in.
It's expensive to live in London.
examples.contextForm: it is expensive to do something

examples.text: It is now more expensive for Europeans to visit here.
examples.contextForm: it is expensive for somebody to do something

examples.text: Food in this country is getting very expensive.
Giving every patient an annual anti-flu injection would be prohibitively expensive.
I found the food very expensive.
Some of these legal cases are enormously expensive.

wordOrigin: early 17th cent. (in the sense ‘lavish, extravagant’): from Latin expens- ‘paid out’, from the verb expendere, from ex- ‘out’ + pendere ‘weigh, pay’ + -ive.
